children.text: The report from the North American Congress on Latin America (NACLA) explains the legal and political battles surrounding Kennecott Copper Company's efforts to coerce compensation for its expropriated Chilean properties. French dock workers' refusal to unload freighters in solidarity with Chile and subsequent legal controversies in Holland, Sweden, and Germany underscore the global repercussions of Kennecott's actions. Despite the State Department's assertion of Kennecott's exercise of legal rights, Forbes Magazine highlights the close coordination between Kennecott and the US government. Such actions, condemned by Chilean political factions and Latin American nations, exacerbate anti-imperialist sentiments and prompt solidarity among copper-exporting countries. Furthermore, US policy backfires as European competitors fill voids left by US companies, intensifying anti-imperialist reactions in South America. At the UN Economic Commission for Latin America session in Quito, South American countries unanimously condemn US economic policy toward the continent, demonstrating the growing resistance to US strategies in the region.

The Latin American Press Review sheds light on revelations regarding US corporations' involvement in undermining the Allende government in Chile, including Secretary of State William Rogers' suggestion to halt US sales to Chile, indicative of American interference. The Guardian details ITT's efforts to collect a $92 million claim despite its role in provoking nationalization, as well as its strategies to thwart the Allende government. Similarly, Kennecott Copper Company's attempts to coerce compensation for its expropriated Chilean properties are outlined, revealing legal and political repercussions. The report from the North American Congress on Latin America (NACLA) delves into the legal and political battles surrounding Kennecott's actions, highlighting global repercussions such as French dock workers' solidarity, legal controversies in various European countries, and condemnation from Chilean and Latin American factions, intensifying anti-imperialist sentiments. Additionally, US policy setbacks arise as European competitors fill voids left by US companies, exacerbating anti-imperialist reactions in South America, as evidenced by unanimous condemnation of US economic policy at the UN Economic Commission for Latin America session in Quito, Ecuador.
At ECLA, Latin American countries displayed unity on development, financing, and critiquing US influence.
Organization of American States meeting, focusing on Latin American countries' pursuit of sovereignty and internal reforms.
Two newspapers offer contrasting views on the anniversary of Brazil's 1964 military coup, one celebrating social progress and the other condemning oppression.
The Nixon administration and US corporations colluded to undermine Chilean President Allende through financial sabotage and electoral interference.
